usage_notes: Very common expression of frustration. Ex: 'J'suis tanné de l'hiver' (I'm fed up with winter)
In Quebec, often used positively to mean 'amazing', unlike in France where it means 'disgusting'
Particularly useful in Quebec's cold climate. Ex: 'Je suis frileuse, je mets ma tuque'
More common than 'trempé' in Quebec. Used in the expression 'mouillé comme une lavette' (soaked through)
Used as an intensifier. Ex: 'C'est ben beau' (It's really nice). Often combined: 'ben ben' (really really)
Very common word to describe something or someone annoying. Ex: 'C'est vraiment achalant!' (That's really annoying!)
Used frequently to describe boring situations or things. Ex: 'C'est plate!' (That's boring!)
Colloquial way to say someone is drunk. Ex: 'Y'é pas mal chaud' (He's pretty drunk)
Often used to describe crowded places. Ex: 'La place était paquetée' (The place was packed)
Used to describe something that's acceptable or decent. Ex: 'C'est correct' (It's okay)
Anglicism commonly used in Quebec. Ex: 'C'est ben fancy ici!' (It's really fancy here!)
Another common anglicism. Ex: 'La journée a été rough' (The day was rough)
Used to describe someone who complains too much or is oversensitive. Ex: 'Arrête d'être bébé!' (Stop being a baby!)
From 'vegetable', used to describe a lazy state. Ex: 'Je feel vedge aujourd'hui' (I'm feeling lazy today)
Used to describe someone who's quick-witted or smart. Ex: 'Elle est sharp en maths' (She's sharp at math)
